description: From Middle English arm, from Old English earm, from Proto-West Germanic *arm, from Proto-Germanic *armaz (“arm”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₂(e)rmos (“a fitting, joint; arm, forequarter”), a suffixed form of *h₂er- (“to join, fit together”).

entries.meaning: The portion of the upper human appendage, from the shoulder to the wrist and sometimes including the hand.
examples: She stood with her right arm extended and her palm forward to indicate “Stop!”

entries.meaning: (anatomy) The extended portion of the upper limb, from the shoulder to the elbow.
examples: The arm and forearm are parts of the upper limb in the human body.

entries.meaning: A limb, or locomotive or prehensile organ, of an invertebrate animal.
The part of a piece of clothing that covers the arm.
A long, narrow, more or less rigid part of an object extending from the main part or centre of the object, such as the arm of an armchair, a crane, a pair of spectacles or a pair of compasses.
examples: The robot arm reached out and placed the part on the assembly line.

entries.meaning: (geography) A bay or inlet off a main body of water.
examples: Shelburne Bay is an arm of Lake Champlain.

entries.meaning: A branch of an organization.
examples: the cavalry arm of the military service

entries.meaning: (figurative) Power; might; strength; support.
(baseball, slang) A pitcher
examples: The team needs to sign another arm in the offseason.

entries.meaning: (genetics) One of the two parts of a chromosome.
A group of patients in a medical trial.

verbs.description: arm (third-person singular simple present arms, present participle arming, simple past and past participle armed)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To take by the arm; to take up in one's arms.

description: From Middle English arm (“poor, wretched”), from Old English earm (“poor, miserable, pitiful, wretched”), from Proto-West Germanic *arm, from Proto-Germanic *armaz (“poor”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₁erm- (“poor, ill”).

adjectives.description: arm (comparative armer or more arm, superlative armest or most arm)

entries.meaning: (UK dialectal, chiefly Scotland) Poor; lacking in riches or wealth.
(UK dialectal, chiefly Scotland) To be pitied; pitiful; wretched.

description: Back-formation from arms (plural), from Middle English armes, from Old French armes, from Latin arma (“weapons”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₂er-mo-, a suffixed form of *h₂er- (“to fit together”), hence ultimately cognate with etymology 1.

entries.meaning: (usually used in the plural) A weapon.
(in the plural) Heraldic bearings or insignia.
examples: The Duke's arms were a sable gryphon rampant on an argent field.

entries.meaning: (in the plural, obsolete) War; hostilities; deeds or exploits of war.

verbs.description: arm (third-person singular simple present arms, present participle arming, simple past and past participle armed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To supply with armour or (later especially) weapons.
examples: The king armed his knights with swords and shields.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative) To supply with the equipment, knowledge, authority, or other tools needed for a particular task; to furnish with capability; to equip.
examples: arm yourselves likewise with the same mind: for he that hath suffered in the flesh hath ceased from sin;

entries.meaning: (transitive) To prepare (a tool, weapon, or system) for action; to activate.
examples: Remember to arm the alarm system before leaving for work.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of a tool, weapon, or system) To become prepared for action; to activate.
(transitive) To cover or furnish with a plate, or with whatever will add strength, force, security, or efficiency.
examples: to arm the hit of a sword; to arm a hook in angling

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To take up weapons; to arm oneself.
(transitive) To fit (a magnet) with an armature.
